chapter.title: About This Document
chapter.para: The purpose of this handbook is to facilitate the installation of &PRODNAME; and offer installation guidelines. This handbook is not a tutorial. It provides basic information that will help you understand &PRODNAME;,but you must adapt this information to suit your own configuration.

chapter.title: Installation Introduction: Prerequisites and System Requirements
chapter.para:
Prerequisites Before getting started, make sure you have the following installed on your local machine:
Java OpenJDK 1.6 (or Oracle's JRE)
Tomcat 7 or higher( or any Servlet Spec 3- Compliant Container), if running the ROOT.war deployment
System Requirements Alongside the prerequisites, choose one of the following deployment strategies. Repose offers two methods for deployment, both of which, are described below.

The Proxy Server (Valve) deployment strategy runs &PRODNAME; as a standalone proxy server which will sit between the requester and the origin service. This deployment strategy runs &PRODNAME; on a different port or a different host than the origin service. Proxy Server (Valve) is a .jar file.

&PRODNAME; will run inside a third party servlet container (e.g. tomcat or glassfish). This strategy allows &PRODNAME; to run on the same container as the origin service. The ROOT.war artifact is a Web application ARchive (WAR). It contains all the components needed to install &PRODNAME; into a running application container. One of these components is a default web.xml that can start up &PRODNAME; in the standard configuration model.

chapter.title: Installing Repose
chapter.para: Repose can either be installed through a Linux package manager (RPM or Debian) or downloaded from GitHub. As previously mentioned,you can choose to install Repose as either ROOT.war in an existing servlet container or the Valve Proxy server. Choose one of the following installations:

para.emphasis: Installing ROOT.war From a Linux Package Manager (RPM)

listitem.para: The instructions for installing ROOT.war from RPM are located at"http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/RPM#RPM-InstallingRPM%27sforROOT.war" RPM installing ROOT.war

para.emphasis: Installing Valve Proxy Server from a Linux Package Manager (RPM or Debian)

listitem.para: The instructions for installing Valve Proxy Server from RPM are located at RPM **Installing Valve Proxy Server.**
The instruction for installing Valve Proxy Server from Debian are located at Debian** Installing Valve Proxy Server.**

itemizedlist.para: Repose can be downloaded from https://github.com/rackerlabs/repose and built with Maven. Once built, the following binaries are created for the different installations:

listitem.para: ROOT.war - The ROOT.war is built at project-set/core/web-application/target/ROOT.war.
Valve Proxy Server - The Valve jar file is located at project-set/core/valve/target/repose-valve.jar.

section.title: Paths for Default Installation Directories
section.para: The directories below are provided during the installation process. These directories cannot be customized. You can find these &PRODNAME; directories by following the appropriate paths:

listitem.para: Repose Valve jar is installed in /usr/share/lib/repose.
Repose ROOT.war is installed in /var/lib/tomcat7/webapps.
Repose start up script is in /etc/init.d.
The &PRODNAME; default config. directory is set to /etc/repose and can be customized in the following methods:
For the Valve Installation, the config directory can be set with the -c command line option. See Starting and Stopping Repose for more information.
For the ROOT.war Installation, the config directory can be set through the web.xml file in the ROOT.war. See Starting and Stooping Repose for more information.
The following directories can be customized using the container.cfg.xml if you do not want to use the default.
Repose deployment folder where ear files get exploded is /var/repose/deployment.
Repose ear files are installed in /usr/share/repose/filters.
Click http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Installation#Installation-MoreaboutDirectoriesto learn more about Repose Directories

section.title: Required Configurations for Deployment
section.para: Below are files of the default configuration settings that are a part of this installation. These default files are required to run &PRODABBREV;.

listitem.para: Edit the defaultsystem-model.cfg.xml that is provided by the installation to point to your origin service.
Edit the default container.cfg.xmlthat is provided by the installation to make sure Repose knows where to look for component artifacts and where to deploy them.
Click"http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Installation#Installation-MoreaboutDirectories"to learn more about Repose Configurations

important.para: To Start or Stop Repose using Valve proxy Server follow: http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/Proxy+Server+%28Valve%29+Configuration#ProxyServer%28Valve%29Configuration-StartingandStoppingRepose
To Start or Stop Repose using the ROOT.war Configuration follow:http://wiki.openrepose.org/display/REPOSE/ROOT.war+Configuration

section.title: Testing Repose
section.para: Send a request to verify that Repose is running: curl localhost:8887 -v Verify Response returns response code 200, and that the "Via" header containing the string "Repose" shows which version of Repose you are running.
For example, part of your response should be in the following form:
section.programlisting: HTTP/1.1 200 OK Content-Type: text/plain Via: 1.1 Repose (Repose/2.7.1-SNAPSHOT) x-request-id: somevalue
section.para:
Repose is running successfully when you send the above request and you are able to run the end service.
Be sure to look at the log files that are generated during the Starting of Repose to debug if you experience any issues.

chapter.title: Filters
chapter.para: Repose can load Java Servlet Filters and process the requests and responses traveling between the client and server. A Filter is an HTTP message interceptor that provides a specific piece of business functionality. A filter contains Repose specific named reference. A Filter Chain is a sequence of filters that will intercept the request from the first filter of the sequence to the last enumerated filter in the sequence.
You can add filters to Repose using the System Model Configuration File. See the system-model.cfg.xml example below. The filter name used in the system-model.cfg.xml are defined in web-fragment.xml

chapter.title: Further Information
chapter.para: Upon successful completion of the Repose installation the following default directories are made accessible. These default directories are described below:

td.para: Stores all the artifacts that Repose has been configured to use.

tr.td: Stores all of Repose's XML configurations in this directory. The ROOT.war deploy assumes this directory is located in /etc/repose. Repose only supports file system configuration locations. Default Location: /etc/repose

td.para: Default location: /var/repose/deployment Repose uses the deployment directory to copy deployed versions of the artifacts it has been configured to use. Define a deployment directory as a writable location.
This stores System logs and HTTP logs.

tr.td: Operating System User and Group Configuration

td.para: Dedicate a User and Group to Repose to improve isolation and selection of Repose's permissions. Be sure the Repose User and Group can write to the file system as well as read configurations stored in the file system.

note.para: All consumable artifacts meant for deployment through Repose must conform to the Java Platform,Enterprise Edition (JEE6)

chapter.para: More About Configurations The following table lists the configuration files that are required for Repose installation and a description of the required file.

td.para: The System Model configuration outlines the entire deployment layout for the service cluster. Repose must be aware of this in order to configure itself and correctly coordinate routing if necessary. The System Model also lets Repose know where the other Repose nodes reside. Using this information, Repose can coordinate its own clustering to help load balance or share data among nodes that share common filters.
The container tells the system where to look for component artifacts and where to deploy them.
